TITLE: Tesla to Require Masks at Nevada Battery Factory
SUMMARY: The Silicon Valley electric vehicle-maker joins others in tightening at-work guidelines to safeguard against the renewed spread of Covid-19.

TITLE: Sexual-Assault Allegation at Alibaba Triggers Outrage, Investigation
SUMMARY: A firestorm of public criticism has prompted Chief Executive Daniel Zhang to intervene in a situation that has stirred questions about sexual harassment in Chinese workplaces.

TITLE: Companies Are Scrapping Their Plans for Fall
SUMMARY: The fast-spreading Delta variant has managers revamping schedules, with bosses delaying office reopenings and canceling events.

TITLE: Renewables Are Fast Replacing Coal, Except in Rural America
SUMMARY: Many utilities are quickly closing coal plants, but the electric cooperatives that serve less-populous areas have been slower to change.

TITLE: When Amazon Customers Leave Negative Reviews, Some Sellers Hunt Them Down
SUMMARY: Sellers on Amazon.com are reaching out to unhappy buyers to revise or delete negative reviews, in exchange for refunds or gift cards—in violation of the terms they agree to on the retail platform.

TITLE: Infrastructure Bill Clears Senate Procedural Hurdle
SUMMARY: The roughly $1 trillion bipartisan bill cleared another hurdle, with 18 Republicans joining Democrats to bring the agreement one step closer to final passage.

TITLE: Infrastructure Bill's Boost to Economy Is Likely to Be Limited
SUMMARY: Investments in highways, ports and broadband under the infrastructure bill are unlikely to have a big impact on growth in the next few years, economists say, but could lead to long-term gains in productivity.

TITLE: Rising Rents Pose Risks to the Fed's Inflation Outlook
SUMMARY: The cost of renting a home has bounced back from a Covid-19 lull, which could drive up the rate of inflation down the road and alter the Fed’s calculations about when to raise interest rates.

TITLE: College Hasn't Helped Close the Wealth Gap for Black Americans
SUMMARY: The wealth of Black college graduates in their 30s has plunged over the past three decades, the result of skyrocketing student loans and sluggish income growth.

TITLE: Alabama Is Home to One of the U.S.'s Tightest Labor Markets
SUMMARY: The city of Birmingham’s diversified economy, an earlier relaxation of Covid-19 restrictions, and limited number of available workers put it in competition with Salt Lake City for the lowest unemployment rate for large metro areas.

TITLE: A Gold Mine Takeover Highlights Increasing Mining-Sector Risk
SUMMARY: Kyrgyzstan’s nationalization of Centerra Gold’s large mining operation is one of the most brazen moves in recent years by a country to assert control over valuable natural resources, mining and legal experts say.

TITLE: U.K. Led the World in Slashing Carbon Emissions. Now Comes the Hard Part.
SUMMARY: Britain has made deeper emission cuts than most major economies. How it fares on further reductions will offer clues to the U.S. and other countries.

TITLE: McDonald's Pushes Diners to Use Trays as Food Bags Run Tight
SUMMARY: The burger chain recently told restaurant owners that they needed to limit orders of bags from suppliers as usage is running ahead of already high numbers last year—the latest supply challenge affecting U.S. restaurants.

TITLE: Disney Lawyer Defends Distribution of 'Black Widow' in Scarlett Johansson Fight
SUMMARY: The lawyer said Disney will seek to move the fight from the courts to arbitration.

TITLE: Biden's Electric-Car Ambitions Face Real-World Roadblocks
SUMMARY: Auto makers want congressional action on charging stations and tax incentives. Consumer support also is needed.

TITLE: To Beat Tesla, Volkswagen Bets on Making Its Own EV Batteries
SUMMARY: Volkswagen, one of the world’s two largest auto makers by sales, could be the world’s biggest maker of electric vehicles as soon as next year—but making a cost-effective EV battery is a challenge.

TITLE: Record Pace for Corporate Earnings Keeps Stocks Buoyant
SUMMARY: Despite a handful of economic risks coming into view, investors have been heartened by a standout earnings season in which the share of big U.S. companies beating profit expectations is on pace for a record.

TITLE: Movie Theater Recovery in a Holding Pattern
SUMMARY: Cinemark and IMAX’s results show that moviegoers are returning, but hardly in droves. High hopes are hanging on the fourth quarter—assuming theaters stay open and studios don’t push more movies into streaming.

TITLE: Uber, Lyft Prices at Records Even as Drivers Return
SUMMARY: Data show average fares were at a record in July despite an improvement in the pandemic-driven shortage of drivers.
